description: Alaska Constitution provisions relevant to child welfare and family rights.
copyright: Project Milk Carton 501(c)(3) - All Rights Reserved

relevant_provisions.name: Search and Seizure
relevant_provisions.text: The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses and other property, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated. No warrants shall issue, but upon probable cause, supported by oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to be searched, and the persons or things to be seized.
relevant_provisions.application_to_cps: CPS removal of a child constitutes a seizure. Alaska courts have interpreted this provision to provide greater privacy protections than the Fourth Amendment. Warrantless removals require exigent circumstances or court authorization.

key_cases.holding: Alaska Constitution provides broader privacy protections than federal constitution; right to privacy in the home is fundamental.
key_cases.relevance: Establishes heightened privacy protections under Alaska Constitution that apply to home intrusions including CPS investigations.

relevant_provisions.name: Right to Privacy
relevant_provisions.text: The right of the people to privacy is recognized and shall not be infringed. The legislature shall implement this section.
relevant_provisions.application_to_cps: Alaska's explicit privacy right provides heightened protection for family autonomy and parental rights. Government intrusion into family matters must meet heightened scrutiny and be narrowly tailored to serve compelling state interests.
relevant_provisions.federal_parallel: U.S. Const. amend. XIV (implied privacy rights)

key_cases.case_name: L.P.M. v. State, Dep't of Health & Soc. Servs.
key_cases.holding: Parents have fundamental liberty interest in care and custody of children under Alaska Constitution; state must meet heightened scrutiny when infringing on parental rights.
key_cases.relevance: Applies Alaska's privacy provision to parental rights in child welfare proceedings.

relevant_provisions.name: Due Process
relevant_provisions.text: No person shall be deprived of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law. The right of all persons to fair and just treatment in the course of legislative and executive investigations shall not be infringed.
relevant_provisions.application_to_cps: Parents have fundamental liberty interest in care, custody, and control of their children. Termination of parental rights requires clear and convincing evidence. CPS proceedings must provide adequate notice, opportunity to be heard, and procedural safeguards.

key_cases.case_name: A.A. v. State, Dep't of Family & Youth Servs.
key_cases.holding: Parents have fundamental constitutional right to raise their children; state must prove by clear and convincing evidence grounds for termination of parental rights.
key_cases.relevance: Establishes due process standards for termination of parental rights under Alaska Constitution.

relevant_provisions.name: Equal Rights and Opportunities
relevant_provisions.text: This constitution is dedicated to the principles that all persons are equal and entitled to equal rights, opportunities, and protection under the law; and that all persons have corresponding obligations to the people and to the State.
relevant_provisions.application_to_cps: CPS policies and practices cannot discriminate based on protected characteristics. Equal protection analysis applies to differential treatment of similarly situated parents or families.
relevant_provisions.federal_parallel: U.S. Const. amend. XIV, § 1 (Equal Protection Clause)

relevant_provisions.name: Trial by Jury
relevant_provisions.text: The right of trial by jury shall be secured to all and remain inviolate. The legislature may provide that the verdict may be by not less than three-fourths of the jury.
relevant_provisions.application_to_cps: Right to jury trial in certain child welfare proceedings where parental rights are at stake. Alaska statutes may provide jury trial rights in termination proceedings.

relevant_provisions.name: Right to Remedy
relevant_provisions.text: Courts shall be open and justice shall be administered without unnecessary delay.
relevant_provisions.application_to_cps: Families have right to timely court proceedings in child welfare cases. Unnecessary delays in hearings or case resolution may violate this provision.

relevant_provisions.name: Remedies for Injuries
relevant_provisions.text: Every person shall have remedy in the law for injuries to person, property, or reputation.
relevant_provisions.application_to_cps: Parents and children may have civil remedies for wrongful removal, false allegations, or violation of constitutional rights by CPS workers. May support § 1983 claims and state tort actions.

relevant_provisions.name: Public Assistance
relevant_provisions.text: The legislature shall provide for public welfare.
relevant_provisions.application_to_cps: State constitutional duty to provide child welfare services and family support. May create affirmative obligations for reasonable efforts to preserve families and provide services.
